issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: Signifies completion of tasks, info requests, etc.
resolution.name: Completed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.description:
(update: setting selinux from enforcing to permissive on the NC resolved this issue. Tested with versions 0.2.1, and 0.2.2 of the eucalyptus-selinux pkg and saw the same behavior with each). 

Opening this to track an issue which we've seen on several setups, but possibly limited to some SAN backends. On several 3par clouds as well as a netapp backed cloud, attached volumes are failing with I/O errors when attempting to write and sometimes read from the underlying block device(s). 

- This seems to only occur when more than one volume is attached to the instance. 
- The last volume attached appears to work fine, all older attachments fail. 
- There are a few logged errors in the NC's /var/log/messages and libvirt logs. Not sure if these are relevant as they appear to be related to detaching volumes, and only appear during detach. 

NC libvirt logged warnings, errors...
{code}
(process:18591): GLib-WARNING **: gmem.c:482: custom memory allocation vtable not supported
2017-01-24T00:13:18.263130Z Device 'drive-virtio-disk4' not found
{code}
 
NC's /var/log/messages:
{code}

fields.summary: EBS volume guest I/O errors when NC SELinux enforcing, and > 1 volume attached

Said [~mclark]: "update: setting selinux from enforcing to permissive on the NC resolved this issue"

I updated the issue title to clarify, this seems more like an SELinux issue than an EBS issue.

To clarify, we've never seen this in DAS or Overlay, right?

When an instance has a volume attached and I attach another one I see a udev change appear for the volume that is already attached:

{code:title=udevadm monitor}
KERNEL[97943.803316] change   /devices/platform/host15/session10/target15:0:0/15:0:0:0 (scsi)
KERNEL[97943.803471] change   /devices/platform/host15/session10/target15:0:0/15:0:0:0/block/sdc (block)
UDEV  [97943.803744] change   /devices/platform/host15/session10/target15:0:0/15:0:0:0 (scsi)
UDEV  [97943.836774] change   /devices/platform/host15/session10/target15:0:0/15:0:0:0/block/sdc (block)
KERNEL[97943.841675] add      /devices/platform/host15/session10/target15:0:0/15:0:0:1 (scsi)
KERNEL[97943.841714] add      /devices/platform/host15/session10/target15:0:0/15:0:0:1/scsi_disk/15:0:0:1 (scsi_disk)

UDEV  [97943.843804] add      /devices/platform/host15/session10/target15:0:0/15:0:0:1/scsi_device/15:0:0:1 (scsi_device)
UDEV  [97943.844325] add      /devices/platform/host15/session10/target15:0:0/15:0:0:1/scsi_generic/sg4 (scsi_generic)
UDEV  [97943.844344] add      /devices/platform/host15/session10/target15:0:0/15:0:0:1/bsg/15:0:0:1 (bsg)
KERNEL[97943.846524] add      /devices/virtual/bdi/8:48 (bdi)
UDEV  [97943.846802] add      /devices/virtual/bdi/8:48 (bdi)
KERNEL[97943.851273] add      /devices/platform/host15/session10/target15:0:0/15:0:0:1/block/sdd (block)
UDEV  [97943.885935] add      /devices/platform/host15/session10/target15:0:0/15:0:0:1/block/sdd (block)
{code}

When udev processes a change event for sdc it gives that device the label it started out with ({{fixed_disk_device_t}}), undoing the label that libvirtd applied ({{svirt_image_t:s0:c21,1018}}), causing this bug.  The same thing can also happen when I instead detach a volume.

When it processes a volume attachment or detachment, does the NC do anything with the other devices?

The dmesg output for the same event mentions the device that corresponds to /dev/sdc only once, in its first line:

{code}
[97942.209664] sd 15:0:0:0: Warning! Received an indication that the LUN assignments on this target have changed. The Linux SCSI layer does not automatical
[97942.231553] scsi 15:0:0:1: Direct-Access     3PARdata VV               3222 PQ: 0 ANSI: 6
[97942.247305] scsi 15:0:0:1: alua: supports implicit TPGS
[97942.247924] scsi 15:0:0:1: alua: port group 01 rel port 3fd
[97942.248292] scsi 15:0:0:1: alua: rtpg failed with 8000002
[97942.248891] scsi 15:0:0:1: alua: port group 01 state A preferred supports tolusnA
[97942.248895] scsi 15:0:0:1: alua: Attached
[97942.249090] sd 15:0:0:1: Attached scsi generic sg4 type 0
[97942.249752] sd 15:0:0:1: [sdd] 2097152 512-byte logical blocks: (1.07 GB/1.00 GiB)
[97942.252560] sd 15:0:0:1: [sdd] Write Protect is off
[97942.252564] sd 15:0:0:1: [sdd] Mode Sense: 8b 00 10 08
[97942.253068] sd 15:0:0:1: [sdd] Write cache: disabled, read cache: enabled, supports DPO and FUA
[97942.262246] sd 15:0:0:1: [sdd] Attached SCSI disk
{code}

Seems to be due to a kernel change. Tried the following 3 kernels, the most recent kernel '514.6.1.el7' is showing this issue.  Looks like the repo updated this version on 1/19/17. 
Test results for the following kernel versions:
514.6.1.el7 - FAIL 
514.2.2.el7 - PASS
327.36.3.el7 - PASS
The problem occurs with the now-current version of RHEL (3.10.0-514.6.1.el7), so it will affect anyone running 4.3 on RHEL7.

The problem occurs as follows:
* When an iSCSI target is attached to a host with our udev rule (installed in {{/lib/udev/rules.d/55-eucalyptus-openiscsi.rules}}), that rule sets the ownership of the block device to {{eucalyptus}} so that the Storage Controller process, running as {{eucalyptus}} can read it. The rule was written to trigger on any event: addition, removal, and a change on a block device, but on a Storage Controller it only has effect when volumes are attached to the host.
* If this udev rule is present on an NC host -- which happens on source installs and on single-node Euca setups -- it will trigger when volumes are attached or detached to the host for hot-plugging them to instances. Furthermore, on some SANs, presumably because of a potential LUN assignment change, the rule also triggers for volumes that are _not_ being attached or detached: those get a 'change' notification.
* The problem with this 'change' notification is that it causes an attached block device to switch ownership from 'qemu' (assigned to it by libvirt, overriding our 'eucalyptus' ownership) back to 'eucalyptus'. The ownership change isn't necessarily problematic. But when SELinux notices the ownership change, it relabels the file object, making its contents inaccessible to the VM, resulting in I/O errors inside the guest.

The solution is to avoid triggering the udev rule on 'change' and 'delete'. It now only triggers on 'add' of block devices:

{code}
diff --git a/clc/modules/block-storage-common/udev/rules.d/55-eucalyptus-openiscsi.rules b/clc/modules/block-storage-common/udev/rules.d/55-eucalyptus-openisc
index 69b8b6f..ce0117f 100644
--- a/clc/modules/block-storage-common/udev/rules.d/55-eucalyptus-openiscsi.rules
+++ b/clc/modules/block-storage-common/udev/rules.d/55-eucalyptus-openiscsi.rules
@@ -1 +1 @@
-KERNEL=="sd*", SUBSYSTEMS=="scsi", PROGRAM="/usr/libexec/eucalyptus/check-iscsi-target-name %b",SYMLINK+="euca-iscsi/%c/partition%n",OWNER="eucalyptus"
+ACTION=="add", KERNEL=="sd*", SUBSYSTEMS=="scsi", PROGRAM="/usr/libexec/eucalyptus/check-iscsi-target-name %b",SYMLINK+="euca-iscsi/%c/partition%n",OWNER="eucalyptus"
{code}

A couple clarifying points:
* udev forces the relabeling as it changes the block device's ownership.
* The change event that occurs in addition to add or remove events is new in kernel-3.10.0-514.6.1.el7.

Fix Verified

Installed Packages
Name        : eucalyptus
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : 4.4.0
Release     : 0.25777.142.20170130git8ef69c1.el7

This issue is no longer present. EBS tests in CI and manual tests have shown the fix has resolved the issue. 

Manual steps:
# launch EBS backed instance
# verify the instance is reachable (if ssh'd to the instance check the file system is writeable)
# attach a new volume to this instance 
# verify the instance can still be reached. (if still ssh'd from earlier ensure the file system is writeable, i.e. no read only warnings)
Moving 4.4.0 Issues from Release Pending to Resolved
